dt: {bc}characterized by affectation of {a_link|grandeur} or splendor or by absurd exaggeration

dt.t: They did not believe his {wi}grandiose{/wi} claims.

dt: {bc}impressive because of uncommon largeness, scope, effect, or grandeur

pt: {sc}grand{/sc} {sc}magnificent{/sc} {sc}imposing{/sc} {sc}stately{/sc} {sc}majestic{/sc} {sc}grandiose{/sc} mean large and impressive. {sc}grand{/sc} adds to greatness of size the implications of handsomeness and dignity.
{sc}magnificent{/sc} implies an impressive largeness proportionate to scale without sacrifice of dignity or good taste.
{sc}imposing{/sc} implies great size and dignity but especially stresses impressiveness.
{sc}stately{/sc} may suggest poised dignity, erectness of bearing, handsomeness of proportions, ceremonious deliberation of movement.
{sc}majestic{/sc} combines the implications of {sc}imposing{/sc} and {sc}stately{/sc} and usually adds a suggestion of solemn grandeur.
{sc}grandiose{/sc} implies a size or scope exceeding ordinary experience
but is most commonly applied derogatorily to inflated pretension or absurd exaggeration.

et: French, from Italian {it}grandioso{/it}, from {it}grande{/it} great, from Latin {it}grandis{/it}
shortdef: characterized by affectation of grandeur or splendor or by absurd exaggeration
impressive because of uncommon largeness, scope, effect, or grandeur
